intro: Atelophragma wallowense, commonly known as the Wallowa rocknettle, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the Pacific Northwest of the United States. It is characterized by its basal rosette of broad, lance-shaped leaves covered in fine, glandular hairs. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers arranged in a dense, spike-like inflorescence. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors and streamside habitats. Its botanical features make it an important component of the local flora, contributing to ecological diversity and soil stabilization.
